name: Kepler-366
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-366 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-366 is a star with 1.0220000000000002 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.05 times its radius. It is located 6390.41 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-366 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-366 b

Kepler-366 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.28 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-366.

The mass of Kepler-366 b is 2.37 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-366 b is 1.46 that of Earth. At 2.37 Earth masses, Kepler-366 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-366 c

Kepler-366 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 12.52 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-366.

The mass of Kepler-366 c is 3.91 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-366 c is 1.79 that of Earth. At 3.91 Earth masses, Kepler-366 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-366, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
